abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Electricity Transmission
            and Distribution Project for Armenia were as follows:
            outcomes were satisfactory, the risk to development outcome
            was low or negligible, the Bank performance was
            satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was also
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: flexibility
            should be built into the project design. The task team and
            International Development Association (IDA) management
            remained flexible throughout project implementation,
            adjusting the project scope, individual project components,
            project schedule, and closing dates as needed to take into
            account the energy sector restructuring and reforms.
            Although the outcomes of these reforms and restructuring
            were highly desirable, they did have a negative impact on
            the pace of project implementation. In order to include
            'local cost sharing', and to reduce the cost, the
            contracts were split so that part of the civil works was
            financed by High Voltage Electric Network CJSC (transmission
            company) (HVEN) and awarded to local contractors. Some
            delays could have been reduced by including all civil works
            under the supply and installation contracts, which suppliers
            can then sub-contract to local firms.
